title: You Better Not Cry: Stories for Christmas
author: Burroughs, Augusten

title: 59 Seconds: Think a Little, Change a Lot
author: Wiseman, Richard
review: Science-based answers to the kind of stuff self-help books try to teach you (and fail).

title: The Most Human Human
author: Christian, Brian
review: Probably my favorite book of the year - covers computing, language, the soul, everything.

title: Surely you're joking, Mr. Feynman
author: Richard Feynman
review: A bunch of short stories about Feynman's life - including stories of picking up girls and solving physics puzzles. Inspiring and entertaining.

title: Little Earthquakes
author: Jennifer Weiner
review: A novel about a group of pregnant women and the obstacles they encounter in their first year after pregnancy. Good read..and re-inforced that I won't be baby-making anytime soon. :)

title: The Diamond Age
author: Neal Stephenson
review: A sci-fi novel that follows a women from an abusive childhood to an epic adulthood -- I loved it because it reminds me of my favorite movie, Puff the Magic Dragon. Also makes interesting observations on how society is structured and what makes people intelligent.

title: The Psychopath Test
author: Jon Ronson
review: An account of the author's investigation into what it means to be a psychopath, his interviews with actual psychopaths and the people who try to diagnose them. Really interesting to see the conclusions he reaches..makes you think.

title: Them
author: Jon Ronson
review: An account of the author's investigation into extremists, terrorists, and the like - it's entertaining and interesting to get a peak into their daily life.

title: Snow Crash
author: Neal Stephenson
review: A thrilling sci-fi novel which touches both on web technologies (coining the term avatar), history, and human languages - all interesting to me.

title: Confessions of a Public Speaker
author: Scott Berkun
review: True tales and techniques from a writer that does a lot of public speaking. It's both funny and full of practical tips, and includes nice insights on the effectiveness of teaching.

title: Switch: How to Change Things When Change Is Hard
author: Heath, Chip, Heath, Dan

title: The Happy Body
author: Aniela Gregorek and Jerzy Gregorek
review: A book and philosophy by two olympic weightlifters on their approach to fitness and health. It includes some great arguments against endurance training and for strength training. The nutrition advice seems well-founded, though some of their beliefs seem lacking in scientific studies (like snacking every 3 meals).

title: A General Theory of Love
author: Thomas Lewis
review: A book about why people connect to and love others (particularly their children), including chapters on our different brains, memory, and evolution. The language is a bit overly florid at times, but it has some great insights.

title: The Pun Also Rises
author: John Pollack
review: Written by a champion punner, this book chronicles the history of the pun, including how its varying popularity (and lack thereof), and the different types of puns. It also argues that puns are a uniquely human skill - something to be proud of. Great for anyone who loves puns!

title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
author: Mark Haddon
review: A story written from the perspective of an autistic teenager. Makes you think about what your thinking process might be like if you were autistic too.

title: Drive
author: Daniel H. Pink
review: An exploration of recent research about what motivates humans, and how it differs from what we believed in the past. Targeted at managers, but relevant to anyone.

title: How to Stop Worrying & Start Living
author: Dale Carnegie
review: A book of anecdotes and tips for reducing the time you spend worrying in life. It has some good ideas, but it also got overly Christian in the end and relied too much on anecdotes.

title: The Selfish Gene
author: Richard Dawkins
review: A book that describes evolution from a gene-centric point of view. It's really interesting, but it is a long read and felt a bit over my head at times.

title: How To Win Friends and Influence People
author: Carnegie, Dale
review: Great read for anyone who works with people - i.e. everyone.

title: Packing for Mars
author: Mary Roach
review: An exploration of the typically unexplored facets of space travel, like astronaut selection, waste elimination, monkey masturbation, and food hydration. I didn't get into it as much as her other books, but it was still a very interesting read.

title: Why We Get Fat
author: Gary Taubes
review: A nice condensation of the research presented in the much longer "Good Calories, Bad Calories". This book disputes the myths that have been propagated for the last 50 years, and actually explains how fat is formed in the body and how one can lose weight accordingly.

title: OMG! I can eat that?
author: Jane Kennedy
review: A cookbook of low-carbified restaurant & comfort food recipes, like fried zucchini chips & cauliflower rice. The photos make me drool, and it excites me that I can still eat these foods and avoid the bad carbs.

title: Cognitive Surplus
author: Clay Shirky
review: A great read about how humans will use their freetime, particularly in regards to the media and the growing ability to produce and not just consume. Particularly relevant if you're working in the social or collaborative space.

title: Superconnect: Harnessing the Power of Networks and the Strength of Weak Links
author: Richard Koch & Greg Lockwood
review: A book about the connectedness between people, and how important connections are. It has a good point, but seemed a little too reliant on anecdotes at times.

title: Programming Google App Engine
author: Dan Sanderson
review: A well written book explaining App Engine, with many chapters dedicated to an in-depth look at the datastore, one of the trickiest parts. Slightly better for Python devs than Java devs.

title: HTML5: Up & Running
author: Mark Pilgrim
review: A humorous, informative, and well-written introduction to various parts of HTML5 - the new semantic tags, multimedia, microdata, geolocation, offline storage, and more.

title: Food Rules
author: Michael Pollan
review: A distilled version of "In Defense of Food", this lists all of his rules in short chapters & skips much of the background/technical reading. If you've already got "In Defense of Food", you'll find this one largely redundant.

title: In Defense of Food
author: Michael Pollan
review: A great read about Michael's opinion on how we should be eating today, and a look at why we are eating so badly. It will make you want to run out and eat some organic leafy vegetables immediately.

title: Stiff
author: Mary Roach
review: A fun read about the history of human cadavers and their use in medical research, including the history of what happens to humans after they die (compost, cremation, burial, etc). Learnt a lot of fun facts from this.

title: Good Calories, Bad Calories
author: Gary Taubes
review: This is Gary's first book on obesity & nutrition research, and is very heavy on the science/research details. It talks a lot about the bad science that got us to where we are today, and in the end it talks about the carbohydrate hypothesis. It's good if you're patient, but if not, go for "Why We Get Fat", which distills the information down to a much easier read.
